revision.text: {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WikiProject Military history|class=FA|A-Class=pass|Southeast-Asian=y|US=y|Cold-War=y}} {{WikiProject Vietnam|class=FA|importance=Loa}} {{WikiProject United States|class=FA|importance=Low}} {{WikiProject International relations|class=FA|importance=Low}} {{WikiProject Cold War|class=FA|importance=Low}} }} {{ArticleHistory |action1=WAR |action1date=22:18, 28 January 2008 |action1link=Wikipedia:WikiProject Military history/Assessment/Krulak Mendenhall mission |action1result=approved |action1oldid=187329214 |maindate= 7 September 2016 |action2=FAC |action2date=02:16, 21 May 2008 |action2link=Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/Krulak Mendenhall mission |action2result=promoted |action2oldid=213854451 |dykdate=2 January 2008 |currentstatus=FA }} {{OnThisDay|date1=2009-09-06|oldid1=312269355|date2=2010-09-06|oldid2=383196442|date3=2013-09-06|oldid3=571578688}} == Dodgy sentence == I'm unwilling to change the direct meaning of a sentence without some confirmation, but I've noticed this in the report section: ::''Krulak asserted at the ARVN officer corps at all levels were very conscious of the Buddhist issue, but believed that most viewed it in a detached manner and '''had''' allowed religious differences to significantly affect their internal military relationship.'' (emphasis mine) Surely this should be "had not"? [[User:Shimgray|Shimgray]] | [[User talk:Shimgray|talk]] | 12:23, 31 December 2007 (UTC) :Yeah, a transcription error. '''[[User:Blnguyen|Blnguyen]]''' (''[[User talk:Blnguyen|bananabucket]]'') 00:02, 2 January 2008 (UTC) Ref 29 needs fixing: "Hammer, pp. 214–214." [[User:Epbr123|Epbr123]] ([[User talk:Epbr123|talk]]) 10:01, 9 May 2008 (UTC) ==Hyphenization?== Hello all, and congratulations on the upcoming Featured status of this article. Observation: As of this writing, this article ([[Krulak Mendenhall mission]]) is ''not'' hyphenated. However, the article for the follow-up mission described ''is'' hyphenated ([[McNamara-Taylor mission]]). Any thoughts on this? Ought there be consistency between the two? Thanks to all for all the hard work on this. [[User:KConWiki|KConWiki]] ([[User talk:KConWiki|talk]]) 03:43, 29 August 2016 (UTC) :I was just going to bring this up.--[[User:Kintetsubuffalo|Kintetsubuffalo]] ([[User talk:Kintetsubuffalo|talk]]) 01:56, 7 September 2016 (UTC) ::Normally when two names are involved, an endash is used - I've just moved McNamara-Taylor mission to comply with this. I agree that this article should probably use an endash too. [[User:Colonies Chris|Colonies Chris]] ([[User talk:Colonies Chris|talk]]) 08:05, 7 September 2016 (UTC) "Adviser?" I think the spelling for 'adviser be changed to 'advisor'? This article is about an American thing, so it should be written in American English, and the preferred spelling is "advisor", not "adviser". — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Puuuj|Puuuj]] ([[User talk:Puuuj|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Puuuj|contribs]]) 21:42, 7 September 2016 (UTC) I agree on the hyphenation with an en-dash. [[User:Tuckerresearch|TuckerResearch]] ([[User talk:Tuckerresearch|talk]]) 11:54, 8 September 2016 (UTC) == Photos? == I am struck by the content of the photos: a portrait of Krulak leads off, a series of canned pix of various persons peripheral to the mission (Kennedy, Diem, etc.) follows, and not a single picture of Mendenhall—half of the named portion of the mission. Surely, there are photos of him out there, probably even of him in S. Vietnam. How about it, Wikipedians? --[[User:Piledhigheranddeeper|Piledhigheranddeeper]] ([[User talk:Piledhigheranddeeper|talk]]) 00:38, 11 September 2016 (UTC)
